reviewText:
Polarity is a first person logic puzzle game whose concept is vastly inspired by Portal. It has similar mechanics but at the same time it is full of originality. The companion cubes might not be as cute as in Portal, but they’re still present in this game and needed to complete the puzzles. An innovation consists in the ability of the player to switch between two polarities (red – blue) which allows him to run through gates or to jump on platforms, according to the selected polarity.

The single player part consists of 14 puzzles that are not too hard to solve, with difficulty increasing  each level though. However, even the most difficult levels can be solved in less than 5 minutes each. The 10 bonus levels are slightly more difficult to figure out, but they add new fun features to the game.

The coop mode, on the other hand, is quite challenging. The two players must cooperate to solve the puzzles that are much more complex than in single player mode. The levels are bigger, now consisting in multiple rooms. The path to the exit isn’t usually the same for the two players, but nevertheless, they need to work together to reach it. There are places in which timed jumps are needed while trying to grab certain objects at the same time, and these jumps are not easily performed with a controller as compared to a mouse and keyboard setup. Sadly, the game offers only local coop and not online multiplayer, so make sure to invite a friend that can be persuaded to work on those together with you, without him losing his patience. Or even better, maybe you can convince him/her to do those tricky jumps :)

Don’t hesitate to buy it, especially discounted, since it is a very fun game!

reviewText:
There’s a sad irony to how Polarity succeeds at being both bloated with ideas and creatively bankrupt.

Every few levels it throws out a new mechanic - binary colored platforms, rotating switches, color changing portals, to name a few - but it barely gives time to show how they function before it decides to move onto something new. The constant stream of introductions to tools that are barely utilized keeps Polarity from ever managing to create puzzles that provide any sort of challenge.

From the main campaign, to the coop levels, and even the bonus stages (which could have just as well been included with the other levels as they feel identical) every puzzle is agonizingly mundane and basic. Polarity mingles in tutorials from start to finish, as if testing my patience for repeating the same handful of puzzle types for hours on end, chuckling to itself at how cleverly it has hidden its simplicity by placing it within tediously large levels that have a habit of breaking halfway through and forcing you to restart.

The cooperative mode itself feels like almost a misnomer, allowing two players to go through levels together but rarely if ever requiring they work together, or even giving both players something to do. Often one of us would simply took over completing a puzzle while the other trailed behind waiting for their turn to help, with a few instances of actual cooperation being the sole highlight of the game.

There just doesn’t seem to be any point to Polarity. It exists for the sake of existing but in a post-Portal world and an increasingly crowded genre, it feels trite and uninspired. I could potentially see a lot of things from it being spun out into better games, but it’s hard to imagine that ever happening when what’s already here is so disinterested in moving forward.

It has taken some things from Portal but it also has alot of original mechanics.

StoryTheres not much of story youre hacking( aka collecting the green things ), and then at the end he gives you money and then he offers you a better job.


AudioThe music is relaxing.
Other effects sound like pretty basic sounds.

GraphicsThis is a unity game so the setting are just presets and resolutions.
The game doesnt look amazing but it does the job theres not really a artstyle.
The only resolutions you have are 1280x720 1360x768 1366x768 and 1600x900.
Other things there are three graphics presets : simple medium and gorgeous.
then you have windowed mode and rebindable keys.


Final verdictSimple fun first person puzzler with some elements of Portal and some original stuff,
with good controls and mediocre graphics but lacking story of any kind.

-HEAVILY inspired

Overall:

reviewText:
Not very difficult, but quite relaxing. Buy on a sale!
More suitable for a younger audience, or simply to relax.

The graphics aren't great, but to be honest it didn't take long to get used to. Considering the game has a cyberspace theme, you wouldn't really expect top quality graphics (or at least I wouldn't, anyways...) So they certainly stood out enough to be easy on the eyes for the duration of the gameplay. I haven't tried Multiplayer so I don't actually know what the player model looks like, so in my ignorance i'll assume it has the same minimalistic appeal.

The audio for this game, I didn't really notice it. That isn't a bad thing - I knew when something happened, but it was more of a confirmation than actual sfx. It added to the feel of calm under pressure, and aided the relaxing puzzles through what could have been frustrating experiences if it wasn't for one problem...

...It was too easy. I finished the game (all data fragments) and all the bonus mission in 92 minutes. It was enjoyable, so I would recommend at a low price, but it certainly wasn't something that I had to struggle to understand the solutions. It took a few attempts to actually do some of the solutions, granted. Some of that was because of a slight issue with physics/momentum that I wasn't expecting. If you are on a moving platform, you will continue to move in that direction as you jump off it. This means that instead of jumping towards what you are looking for you have to account for a slight air drift. Which, again, wasn't difficult to understand, just wasn't as expected initially.

I don't know if this game was supposed to be for a younger audience, or if I am better at this game than others. Personally I felt like the bonus missions should have been part of the main missions, but if the game was meant to be a little easier I can understand why the difficulty would be at a mismatch in that situation. There were 22 levels (including bonus levels) for Singleplayer mode, and I assume 15 for multiplayer - given there are 3 fragments per level and 45 set to CoOp mode. All the same, I was sort of expecting more challenging puzzles, but I didn't dislike the experience up to the end goal.

I doubt this game would get a great deal of re-runs. The base price is not worth the content in my opinion. That being said, I got this game around 90% off (maybe more) and I certainly think this game would be worth it at a discounted value. I have seen this game on sale many, many times. So long as it is half price or better, I would say go for it. As it stands, however, my view is that the game should be around four times longer, with much more challenging rooms in order to justify the retail value asked. Or maybe include a level editor and allow workshop support, but that is likely above the developer's skill level judging by the content provided. Again, not a bad thing, as I in no way disliked the levels that I played, I just don't think that there is  enough  content provided...

PS - Technically, you can get this game at such a steep discount that you could sell the trading cards and make money, though if you are into that kind of thing you'd already know that without reading this review.

reviewText:
Polarity feels like an incomplete game.

The levels are uninteresting and bland, and the puzzles aren't challenging; it actually feels like there was meant to be a lot more to the game than there is, but the developer got tired of the project and decided to wrap it up early.

If you're an achievement hunter, you better have an extra gamepad available for co-op or you'll be unable to complete everything. I personally got the two player section done alone, but I'm not sure how you'd do it without a gamepad. There's also some kind of alarming screeching noise that happens at random, which I want to assume is supposed to be the players communicating, but more realistically it might just be an audio glitch.

If you're into Portal, maybe grab this while it's on sale or in a bundle, but there isn't enough content here to justify the full price. The potential was there, but it fell short and hit the ground hard.

reviewText:
May 19, 2015
Polarity is likely overrated, due to a massive number of people getting the game for 0.19USD and spamming reviews. However, I do feel the game is a reasonable purchase, especially at a discount of -50% or more. Gameplay is simple and enjoyable, while the game has many rough edges and limited content.

The biggest issue I can see is that the game is a sloppy Unity project. The launcher has limited resolution options, and the Steam overlay would ghost on the black borders. Level assets have cracks and seams, buggy lighting, and a major lack in refinement. Some puzzles can be broken by tricks, especially in co-op. Turrets are not solid, and can be ran through. Cubes above a door can be grabbed before the door closes, trivializing later sections. Co-op can be fully completed as one person flipping between keyboard and controller. Later co-op puzzles seemed to have extra cube-locks with no function, with no lines to show what platform was affected. Polarity has the hallmarks of the first game from a company, flawed but passionate.

I enjoyed the game enough to bother with co-op and put up with the sloppy level design to 100% the game. The current content is around 4 hours, with levels consistently taking 3-6 minutes to complete. I liked that timing and pacing, as I could play the game while waiting on friends or multiplayer queues. Puzzles were satisfying and reasonable, and only the cube transformation field (yellow particles) was confusing, with no introduction to even show it exists. The developers could make several improvements, but the game was quite enjoyable. The -96% sale was amazing, but I think the game is worth more than that. Polarity is a decent puzzle option to spend a little time thinking, but this gem is quite rough.

reviewText:
(PLEASE NOTE THAT THIS IS ONLY A REVIEW FOR THE SINGLEPLAYER CAMPAIGN. I'LL EXPLAIN WHY LATER IN THE REVIEW)

I don't know what I expected for four dollars (though I got it for 19 cents), but apparently this isn't it.

GameplayIt felt way too short, but that was probably just because they kept repeating the same puzzles/parkour stunts over and over again, such as when you have to switch polarity in midair to stay on/avoid the platforms/lasers. There were about 5-7 actually unique puzzles.
Also, the mechanics weren't being used enough, such as the on/off switch and the rotation buttons. Even the polarity was mostly just used for either the midair-polarity-switch stunt or fields that blocked certain cubes.
Plus, the data fragments were placed in awkward positions and it didn't feel like they had anything to do with the puzzle at hand. 3/10

EnviromentThere's no real plot aside from being informed that you are hacking into some super important company (although it doesn't look like you're in cyberspace). We are never told what this company is, what they do, or why we need to hack into it.
The scenery never changes, either. We aren't showed where we are before we take up the offer, we aren't shown how we get transported into cyberspace, we aren't shown how we get beamed out once we finish the mission, and we aren't shown where we are when we get the massive supply of credits.
And it's completely clean with no props or broken walls anywhere, despite the numerous video games that showed us that messier was better. Portal had the famous Rattmann dens, Portal 2 had the facility beat up and destroyed in many of the chambers, Gateways had the laboratories broken into by a messy criminal, etc. And just because it's in cyberspace doesn't mean you can't make some areas briefly be replaced with nonsense code before automatically repairing itslef or have the lights take a while to turn on.
Final note: There's just too much black and dark gray on the walls, floors and ceilings, especially in the later levels of the game and the bonus levels. Wouldn't hurt to make it half-light, half-dark like Portal. 2/10

Co-opI do not have any friends who are willing to come over to my house just to play Portal 2 minus the portals. Either way, I don't think it would be that much of an improvement. 2/10

The store pagedoesn't contain that much content from the real, finished game. As a matter of fact, from the looks of it, the prototype was better than the real thing. It contains some final levels with a better balance of dark and light, and one level that was two from the finished product put together.
The description contains numerous flaws. One of the most fun puzzle/platformers since Portal." is a little bit too egotistical and not very true. "Polarity takes it to the next level
date: demanding all of your wits and reflexes." is hardly true at all. I finished all of the singleplayer levels with all of the fragments in around 114 minutes
recommended: and I only stumbled across 2 levels that required reflexes (along with the numerous midair-polarity-switch stunts) and they were pretty easy. "Full-featured local co-op campaign." I am not sure about. 2/10\n\nOverallThis game is hardly worthy of your money
hoursPlayed: even if it's only nineteen cents. 2/10"

That was Polarity in a sentence (And a half, I guess). Now, it's time for the real review.

Basic Info:
Polarity, greatly inspired by Portal, is a first-person puzzle platformer. You can play singleplayer or multiplayer. Either way, they're the same kind of puzzles.

List of Basic Uses:
-Cubes: Used to activate switches, platforms, laser walls, etc.

-Polarity: You switch your Polarity (Your color, some say) to jump onto colored platforms, or to get through a laser gate without dying.

-Gold Lasers, A.K.A. Color Changing Lasers: These are lasers that you can throw cubes into to change their color from either red to blue, or blue to red.

-Data: These are collected to unlock more levels throughout the game and eventually unlock the bonus stages. There are three per level.

reviewText:
Presentation
Polarity is like a simpler and shorter version of Portal, but that doesn't necessarily make it a bad game or a relentless copy of the game which obviously inspired it, as there are plenty of concepts and ideas that make this title stand on its own. To begin with, there are no actual portals, as the game relies on its blue-red polarity concept to solve puzzles, allowing you to change your polarity in order to pass obstacles and reach otherwise inaccessible areas. As that alone would become boring, companion cubes show up just at the right time to throw in the extra element that allows certain levels to present you with challenging puzzles, without over-complicating them to the point where you don't know what to do next. Cubes, just as yourself have polarities as well, however their polarity can only change in special areas, forcing you to use what you have at your disposal in order to solve puzzles, and since you can only summon a limited number of cubes, the solution will always pop up once you've exhausted all other options, making puzzles challenging, but not unsolvable. Unlike Portal, Polarity doesn't have a background story, and there is nothing to tie in one level to the next one, making your entire adventure feel without purpose, especially since the single player campaign can be finished in less than an hour.
Rating: 6.5

Gameplay
The gameplay is simplistic and accessible to anyone, as it only requires basic character and camera movements and control buttons for switching polarity and interacting with cubes and other objects, but aside from that logic is the only tool you need in Polarity. Puzzles are challenging, but they never get to the point where they become hard or unsolvable without consulting a guide, mostly because the game will be over before the level design reaches that point. There are a lot of interesting features packed in the final levels, and there was definitely room for a lot more afterwards, but unfortunately none of those features reached their full potential, as the level design remains basic, even when there are more elements involved, as the solution will always be obvious once you take a look around you. The polarity switch is the game's greatest strength as it creates opportunities for clever and unique puzzles, but once again this feature never goes beyond that basic gate, making it feel unused in most cases. There are some interesting puzzles to have fun with, but even so it shouldn't take you longer than four minutes to solve each one, as you will always find the solution to each one once you've failed on your first attempt and realize the answer is the other way around.
Rating: 6

Graphics
The game looks okay for what it is, however even with the test chamber look inspired by Portal, there was room for a few details to differentiate one level from another, but in this case all the levels look similar and the only thing to set them apart one from another is the placement of the objects required to solve the puzzle. The visual effects are basic, and once again for what this game is, they do the job, even though in certain areas better effects would've made a difference in the sense of power the game tries to give you by interacting with its objects.
Rating: 5.5

Audio
There are no voices in here since there is no background story, narration or characters, leaving the entire experience up to the level design and the puzzles, but the lack of such things only makes the game seem shorter than it already is. The sound effects are basic and repetitive, as you will still hear the same interaction sounds over and over again; the soundtrack is limited and even though it is in theme with what the game offers, you will eventually grow tired of hearing that same tune all the time.
Rating: 4

Extras
Apart from the single player campaign, there is a Co-Op campaign which consists of a collection of levels designed for two players and a Bonus campaign which can be accessed once you've finished the main missions; all that added up and you've still got only 2-3 hours worth of content.
Rating: 6.5

Verdict
Polarity is a fun game to play if you fancy the genre, however don't expect this to have anything else to offer besides its gameplay concepts, and even with that in mind there is not much to play; after all, this is a 5€ title.
Rating: 5.7

Check out the full review and a lot more about Polarity at http://gamedragons.net/viewtopic.php?f=7&t=338

reviewText:
Polarity is the poor man's Portal, but perhaps that's being a bit unfair to Polarity; it IS its own game in its own right. It doesn't have an incredibly engaging story to it (in fact, save for a short text introduction at the beginning of the game, there's no story to it at all), but at the same time it doesn't really need one. The objective of each level is to use colored cubes to activate corresponding gates and switches to get to the end-level warp while collecting data fragments.

HIGHS: --Gameplay is fun and engaging, albeit a bit bare-bones.
--Bonus levels and Co-op campaign add much needed replay.
--The music (or I should ambience) is soothing without becoming repetitive. Accompanied with the easy-on-the-eyes visuals, the game is actually quite calming (in the good way).


LOWS: --The levels aren't incredibly challenging. They're enough to make you think, but none will really stump you or leave you stuck.
--There's a couple important details the game neglects to inform you about. For example, later in the game you'll encounter yellow gates that, turns out, change the color of whatever cube passes through it. An attentive player would be bound to figure this out on their own eventually, but the more casual player may not be so quick to catch on (especially when the FIRST none-red/blue gate you encounter without being informed kills you).
--The game is FAR too short, especially for the asking price of $10.99 (The single player campaign can be finished in less than an hour, even if you're not the greatest at puzzle games). The game could've, and SHOULD've, been much longer; especially with the multitude of potential puzzles the aforemention yellow gates can bring to the table.


BUY or BYE: I say buy, especially if you're a big fan of the Portal series or puzzle games in general. Polaris is not worth the default $11. A good default price would be $5 (perhaps $9.99 at the most), but certainly not $11. HOWEVER, it IS a fun puzzle game that should be experienced, and for the current sales price of $0.54, you can't go wrong!

reviewText:
This... this is the perfect type of game for giving an 'eh' or neutral review, but I can't.   It's such a quintessentially human act to try to confine judgments or opinions to pure dichotomies.  Steam.  Anyway!

I do think that Polarity - or Portal without Portals, if you like - has a good, if fairly derivative, concept.  Essentially, in lieu of having a portal gun, one can simply change their own polarity, which manifests in either being Red or Blue.  Like colours pass like barriers, and this mechanic (sadly under-used) also applies to the transportable blocks which act as energy keys to platforms, doors and so on.  The player is required to synergise aim, timing and puzzle-solving skills, but the levels never reach that beautiful climax of having length, difficulty and multi-modal challenge in one playable experience.  Things just don't scale up in an intuitive or exciting way; I don't think there are enough mechanics employed  throughout and I don't think the mechanics used have been pushed to their limits.  The relatively short length of the game also contributes to this prosaicness, I think.

The total lack of a plot hurts the game.  The data files that players can optionally collect as they journey through the database they're supposedly hacking could have been used to provide background -- why is this data important?  Who is hiring you and why?  Is what you're doing 'right', or does morality even matter in this situation?  Instead, we get a few throwaway lines about earning a bunch of credits and being hired by a company we know absolutely nothing about.   Another perhaps unexpected side-effect of the lack of plot is that, since quite a few levels look similar to each other, they don't really have enough of an identity in their own right.   When the mechanic is used as the Jewel in the Game Crown and it's great, a significant plot isn't necessarily that important... but it wasn't great here and the game really could have used at least more than it had.

The game works.  Movement isn't always smooth, and the camera was somewhat too sensitive in my opinion, but the puzzles all work as intended and they aren't chance-based.  This is good.  The blocks throw fairly well considering there's only one strength setting, although they don't interact at all well with walls and tend to clip poorly.  Having the choice to sprint is appreciated, and the mechanics are intuitive and make sense without needing much explanation -- over-explanation (or the need for it) is a flaw of quite a few modern games.  The graphics and sound are functional but don't excite in their own right.  I'll concede that the relative lack of interesting sound doesn't abjectly cripple the game, and I did enjoy the different coloured hues used in some rooms.  I just got a bit bored of seeing the same tiling in every room and think that even ambient music could have added contouring to the gamescape.

I don't have a gamepad, so I effectively can't comment on the co-op mode.  I wish that the co-op section didn't have achievements, but that's another topic for another day.

In summary, I'd say that it's a good base idea, but it's lacking in finesse, inspiration and length.  When you're selling a game devoid of plot completely on the mechanic and the mechanic hasn't been used to its full potential, it comes off as underwhelming.  It isn't Portal and it didn't grab me, I'm afraid, but it is an acceptable functional, working game.

reviewText: I'm not quite sure how this game is rated so well. I mean, it's not entirely without merit, but it is entirely without a novel idea. reviewText: Fantastic little puzzler. Nothing too taxing on the brain, but attempting to find all of the data packs (there are three of them hidden in each level) can be a real challenge and the idea of polarity-switching is used to good effect. The similarities to Portal are well-known at this point; you find yourself in a sleek, enclosed environment and use your wits (and cubes) to reach the exit. If you enjoyed Portal, you'll enjoy this, but it would be doing the game a disservice to call it a Portal clone; it has its own ideas and systems that are well thought-out and smoothly executed throughout.\n\nThe game is void of any real plot or humour, but those things aren't needed here. It's a simple little game and quite a relaxing way to flex your puzzling muscles for an hour or two, without any extra baggage forcefully added on. I've not been able to enjoy the co-op campaign just yet, but if the singleplayer is anything to go by then it must be a lot of fun. There's certainly potential for a sequel here and I hope to see more from this developer in the future.

reviewText:
Polarity is a fairly simple 3D first-person puzzle platformer.  It's rather short; I beat the single player game in one sitting in an afternoon.  The game also contains a split-screen co-op mode and a set of bonus levels.

It lacks a lot of polish that makes similar puzzle games great: the menus are rather old looking, although the level select in the background is nice; there are a few clipping errors here and there, but nothing overt; the textures are a little flat, but there are is a nice shadow effect around the edges of things that make everything look a little bit nicer.

The single player puzzles are rather easy, and the co-op puzzles seem to be a bit harder.  However, it seems that the co-op mode has even less polish than the main game, with the cube spawn sites not even having the fancy model that the single player campaign uses.

I'd rate this game as a fairly good entry into the genre for someone who hasn't played much.  But for anyone looking for a well polished game or much of a challenge, it's best to look elsewhere.

reviewText:
Polarity is an overall very nice, Portal-like experience.


PROS:

- The puzzles are relatively simple, but engaging.

- The gameplay is good and makes you want to keep progressing through the levels.

- The minimalistic style is pleasant to look at.

- The music is very relaxing and a joy to listen to.


CONS:

- I found the sound effects to be so annoying that after the first level, I went into the options to see if I can lower their volume - for some reason you can only turn them on and off, and I was forced to do the latter. The game doesn't really lose much if you do, and you are able to fully immerse yourself in the music that way.

- Some of the level design choices aren't particularly fortunate, like how you can't always be sure where the platform you're standing on ends, or how deadly pits and normal ground are so hard to tell apart. Also, the chambers tend to be too dark and big sometimes.

- 2 or 3 levels require quickly changing the polarity mid-jump, which is a pain to accomplish sometimes.

- The singleplayer campaign is pretty short, and together with the bonus levels, it can be completed in about 3 hours. (I didn't try the coop one yet, so there's that...)

- The ending could offer something more satisfying than just a few lines of text...


CONCLUSION:

Definitely get it if it's on sale. Especially the one that lowers its price to laughable 20 cents.

reviewText:
This game isn't great.
But it's not terrible, either.
It sits quite firmly in the 'good' category.

I had fun playing it, but it's fairly short, and not all that difficult. Still, the platforming is solid, the controls are fine, and the puzzles are challenging enough that you need to pay attention to the game, but not so much so that you really have to work yourself to solve them.
It's a good relaxation game; good for taking your mind off stuff that's troubling you, without adding any stress on top of what you've got.
There were a couple minor bugs, but nothing major. The collisions just went a bit wonky in a couple places.
There isn't enough here for me to recommend it at full price, but if you can pick it up on sale (I got it for 21 cents), then definitely grab it.
Unless you hate puzzle platformers, in which case you probably won't like this game.
Because it's a puzzle platformer.

reviewText: It's hard to recommend this game but I feel overall it was a positive experience for me but it just barely made it for me. I completed the single player mode and bonus mode. I felt for a puzzle game it was extremely easy. The puzzles never really feel like puzzles, they don't require problem solving skills or thought, it's mostly trial and error or find the object and bring it here mixed with some minor platforming. It's also a very short game that had a lot of rough edges and minor bugs that held it back from being a better experience. There were a lot of interesting mechanics and ideas in this game but they aren't really used to a greater extent. They introduce new mechanics but never actually use them later in a compelling and challenging way. Because of that it comes off as a bit gimmicky. A bunch of interesting ideas never fully realized. Graphical issues were also a bit of an eyesore but overall the game looked okay.\n\nThis could be a great puzzle game if more time was put into it and it was polished up a bit. More puzzles and more thought put into their design would really improve the gameplay as well. Currently though, it's just an okay puzzle game for a cheap price. If you like puzzle games and cheap prices, than this is worth a decent hour of your time.
